comment.author: 71043199@N07
comment._content: I have located him in the Canadian Expeditionary Force database. Lt. Frederick Vernon Jones, 48th Highlanders, from Toronto, Ontario. www.collectionscanada.gc.ca/databases/cef/001042-119.01-e...

comment.author: 62508825@N00
comment._content:
CEF database above has attestation paper of Lt. Frederick Vernon Jones signed on 22 Sep 1914.
Born: 6 Aug 1882 in Toronto, Ontario, Canada.  
Father: Alphonse F. Jones
Civil Engineer
unmarried
At time of signing, was serving in the 3rd Cdn Mounted Rifles 5R.
5'-7", dark complexion and hair, greenish grey eyes
Church of England.
Scattered handwritten notes on the attestation paper 
state: 15 Bn      Officer      48th Highlanders     Prisoner of War

Could not find an entry for him in the Canadian 1901 Census but found his father Alphonse who was living in E York, Toronto - said to have been born  in 1851.

comment.author: 62508825@N00
comment._content: Lt F V Jones, 15 Bn was held prisoner of war at Kriegsgefangenlager, Bischofsworda (sic), Sachsen, Germany before September 1916 as reported in 4 Nov 1916 Calgary Herald www.rootsweb.ancestry.com/~abwcobit/NewsExtract/1916Calga... OR www.rootsweb.ancestry.com/~abwcobit/NewsExtract/1916Calga... Tantalisingly, a Canadian Great War Project image of a Lt V A Jones - showing a striking likeness to Lt F V Jones in my opinion - together with other officers including Lt H A Barwick, 15th Battalion C.E.F. and entitled Canadian Prisoners of War (Bischofswerda, Saxony, 1915-1916) can be seen here www.canadiangreatwarproject.com/general/imageGeneral.asp?... Lt Barwick was captured at the 2nd battle of Ypres, April 1915.

comment.author: 64288588@N05
comment._content: He is with his family at the time of the 1901 census, but shown by his middle name of Vernon. In the 1911 census they are living at Lawrence Park, York South, North Toronto, Ontario. Parents shown as Alphonse F & Alice B Jones. Frederick's occupation Engineer on the Railway.

comment.author: 15497692@N04
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/62508825@N00] Lt. V. A. Jones is a mis-print, I believe, on this photo. The individual is Frederick Vernon Jones. All of the POWs in this photo attended Upper Canada College. It was featured in the Christmas issue 1916: archive.org/stream/collegetimesc1916uppe#page/n11/mode/2up. G. M. Alexander, H. A. Barwick, R. Y. Cory, F. V. Jones and F. J. Smith in the photo all served with 48th Highlanders and are mentioned in The Red Watch available at archive.org/details/theredwatchwithf00curruoft

comment.author: 15497692@N04
comment._content: Bios on all of the individuals in the POW photo are also provided in The Roll of Service of Upper Canada College 1914-1919 / The War Book fo Upper Canada College here: archive.org/details/warbookofupperca00youn The POW photo is featured again at the back of this volume: archive.org/stream/warbookofupperca00youn#page/305/mode/2up Type persists. I have a copy of the photo and a list of names were provided with it which lists Lt. Frederick Veron Jones. The bios within the volume support this.
